awd_abstract_narration:
This CAREER award funds the research activities of Professor Ciaran Williams at the State University of New York, University at Buffalo. 

The newly upgraded Large Hadron Collider (LHC) represents one of mankind's most technologically advanced and scientifically ambitious projects. By colliding elementary particles against each other at high energies at the LHC, physicists expect to learn about the fundamental building blocks of matter and their interactions at higher energies and smaller distances than have ever been previously explored. The LHC has recently begun its second extended data-taking period (Run II), and it is hard to envisage a more exciting time in particle physics. Run II will test whether the recently discovered Higgs boson is fully consistent with our current expectations, or whether it behaves in ways that transcend our best current theories.  Another primary aim of the LHC program is to seek a microscopic theory of Dark Matter, which is currently poorly understood, and to understand whether there exist any interactions of Dark Matter with more traditional kinds of matter. Research in this area thus advances the national interest by promoting the progress of science in one of its most fundamental directions: the discovery and understanding of new physical law. All of these analyses require precise theoretical predictions in order to extract useful information from the data, and Professor Williams will carry out detailed analyses along these lines. Specifically, Professor Williams will perform new calculations using recently developed methods which will result in a much smaller theoretical uncertainty than those which have previously been used. The results of his calculations will be released publicly to both experimental and theoretical users and will be utilized in experimental analyses. Professor Williams will also establish an educational outreach program, targeting a minority population (Native Americans) which are one of the most under-represented in the sciences.   By working directly with SuperIntendents from the local Native-American school districts, Professor Williams will, over the lifetime of the award, arrange after-school programs and as well as field trips to the Fermilab National Accelerator laboratory. 

More technically, Professor Williams will perform cutting-edge calculations at Next-to-Next-to Leading Order accuracy and beyond, and implement these results into a publicly available computer code, MCFM. The primary focus will be key LHC processes such as diboson production and those related to studies of the Higgs boson. Beyond the Standard Model (BSM) effects will be included, typically in the form of anomalous couplings, allowing for applications in experimental analyses. Prof Williams will also develop methods for regulation of infrared singularities and apply this techniques to new processes of phenomenological relevance.

por.por_cntn:
This project  provided accurate theoretical calculations for the ongoing physics program at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). The machine is operating to such high standards that in order match the precision of the experimental data, the theoretical calculations have to be significantly extended beyond previous results. This is achieved by computing terms systematically in a perturbative expansion in the strong coupling. The standard for most analyses at the LHC is to include two terms in the expansion, so called Next-to-Leading Order (NLO). NLO calculations typically are accurate to approximately 10-30%, which is significantly worse the experimental uncertainty on the best analyses (of around 5-10%). In order to match this level of accuracy at least three terms in the expansion must be included, which is known as Next-to-Next-to Leading Order (NNLO). This project computed NNLO predictions for a variety of important processes at the LHC. Additionally the project developed new tools to allow for even more precise calculations (at Next-to-Next-to-Next-to Leading Order, N3LO) for the future of the high-luminosity LHC program. Upon completion of each calculation the results are made available to LHC experimentalists (and other theorists) through their incorporation into the public Monte Carlo code, MCFM, for use in the ongoing analysis of LHC data. 

This project resulted in several high profile calculations being completed, including the standout result of the N3LO calculation of the decay of a Higgs boson to bottom quarks, and the first NNLO accurate predictions for inclusive photon production at NNLO. These projects generated several other important projects, such as the NNLO calculation of Higgs plus jet through bottom fusion, and the ratio of MET+jet to photon+jet at NNLO, a vital requirement in the ongoing search for Dark Matter at the LHC. In total the project resulted in 12 published papers in highly regarded journals. 

Aside from the scientific research describe briefly above, this project also has broader impacts related to the education of high school students in a rural high school in Western New York. Located on a Native American reservation 50 miles from Buffalo, the Salamanca high school has many complicated socio-economic issues which can hinder the opportunities presented to their students. From 2017 until the start of the Covid pandemic in 2020 the PI ran an after-school physics club at the high school. The aim of the club was to help engage the students in physics, assist in their ongoing coursework, and provide mentors to the students by bringing out University at Buffalo students as helpers. In addition a field trip to Fermilab was organized in 2018 which brought eight students and two teachers for a tour of the Lab's facilities and restored Prairie landscape. The whole trip was a fantastic success. Of the eight students severn were female, and two self identified as Native American. Our trip received media attention, particularly the Fermilab social media. The students toured the facilities, had a meeting with Debbie Harris, a spokesperson for the NuMI/MINERvA experiments, they also had a guided tour of the Fermilab prairie by the Fermilab natural areas group. 

 

In summary this award resulted in intellectual merit from providing advanced theoretical predictions at N3LO and NNLO in QCD for several critical LHC processes. For the broader impact the project trained undergraduate and graduate students in advanced research skills and ran an outreach program at high school located on a Native American reservation.
